Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: HI-LIGHT - Solar Thermal Chemical Reactor Technology for Converting CO2 to Hydrocarbons
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project relates to the fact that the extraction and consumption of fossil carbon accounts for over 6 billion metric tons of CO2 emissions each year. While some mitigation approaches are fairly mature, like capturing CO2 for equestration or for enhanced oil recovery, they are very expensive in terms of both variable and capital costs and have little chance of ever providing a return on investment. By not viewing fossil fuels and feedstocks through a circular economy lens, we estimate these companies miss an opportunity for approximately $50 billion per year in potential profit from hydrocarbons, including methanol, that could be made with waste CO2. If successful, our HI-Light reactor will enable a new economy based on the conversion of fugitive CO2 into useful hydrocarbons and solve the return on investment problem.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop HI-Light, a solar-thermocatalytic "reverse combustion" technology that enables the conversion of CO2 and water to methanol and other hydrocarbons at rate significantly greater than the state of the art. Previous approaches are limited by two roadblocks: (1) the semiconductor catalysts can only use photons with energies greater than their bandgap, which is a small fraction of those present in sunlight and (2) a large fraction of the catalyst material in these reactors is under-utilized due to sub-optimal light and reactant delivery. Our unique reactor uses a patented, multiscale approach to enhance light and reagent transport directly to the reaction site and makes use of traditionally unused photons to provide heat and enhance reaction efficiency. The unique features of our reactor are (1) optimized light delivery to ensure that all of the catalyst material has enough light to activate the reaction and (2) an advanced nano-engineered photocatalyst which is functionalized with ligands to enhance CO2 capture and conversion. The goal of this Phase I effort is to construct an integrated prototype reactor and evaluate its productivity in terms of the grams of hydrocarbon produced per gram of catalyst per hour and demonstrate a 10x improvement over the state of the art.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background

 As the end product of combustion reactions that release large amounts of energy, CO2 is a very stable molecule. While it may be possible to convert CO2 into CaCO3 without breaking the carbon-oxygen bonds, this remains a niche product. A unique recent approach has been to “reverse combustion” by putting in large amounts of energy to convert CO2 into a higher value hydrocarbon product. These approaches use a catalyst optimized for the energy source which can be thermal, radiant, or electrical. For example, one competing approach in development uses geothermal energy to produce electricity to drive an electro-catalytic reaction to convert CO2 to liquid hydrocarbons. This has recently been implemented on a pilot scale by Carbon Recycling International in Iceland. However, this relies on geothermal resources only available in certain geographic locations, and uses electrical energy which may be better utilized for other purposes. Our proposed approach uses solar energy (both radiant and thermal) to perform the reverse combustion reactions in a photocatalytic reactor cell, taking advantage of a resource that is abundant and underutilized in many locations. While photocatalytic production of “solar fuels” has been a research topic for over 20 years, current reactors in the published literature report very low productivity, and this technology has not yet transitioned from the lab to the commercial market.

Intellectual Merits:

This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase II project is a collaborative effort between Dimensional Energy and Cornell University focused on advancing our novel HI-Light reactor towards practical deployment.  Our approach solves the two major roadblocks in photo-conversion of CO2: (1) the semiconductor catalysts can only use photons with energies greater than their bandgap, which is a small fraction of those present in sunlight and (2) a large fraction of the catalyst material in these reactors is under-utilized due to sub-optimal light and reactant delivery.  Our unique reactor uses a patented, multiscale approach to enhance light and reagent transport directly to the reaction site and makes use of traditionally unused photons to provide heat and enhance reaction efficiency. 

Summary of Outcomes:

At Dimensional Energy, we are developing HI-Light – a photo-thermo-catalytic reactor technology that enables the conversion of CO2 and water to synthesis gas at a rate significantly greater than the state of the art.  The unique feature of our technology is that it uses embedded optical waveguides to evenly distribute light within the reactor, increasing the efficacy of the catalyst and ultimately the productivity of the system.  In Phase I we: constructed a fully functional integrated prototype reactor, demonstrated continuous operation for over 24hrs without loss of performance, and showed productivity in terms of the grams of hydrocarbon produced per gram of catalyst per hour that exceeded the state of the art.  In addition, we were able to close a joint development contract with a major petrochemical company to further support the development of our reactor, increased our team to include additional business and technical personnel, and developed relationships with several high-profile venture based funders.  Based on our customer discovery efforts during Phase I, our primary Phase II technical goals will be to construct an upscaled reactor with at least 10x the productivity of our current system, explore a broader space of catalysts to further enhance our conversion efficiency, perform a continuous run for at least 1 week, and demonstrate system level operation of the system through the use of real flue gas.  Successful completion of these goals will facilitate attracting the larger scale capital required to bring the technology to market.

Closing:

Through engaging with the NSF on this Phase 1 project, Dimensional Energy has significantly de-risked our technology, refined our value proposition, and identified a clear path to market. If the HI-Light Technology is deployed at scale, it will play a key role in multinational strategies to draw down atmospheric carbon dioxide with the hopes of stabilizing our potential climate crisis.
